Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundan

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? The chara

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators be like, "The c

Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "t

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a br

We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but it's

We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I remembe

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I remember the t

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history boo

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We di

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of

It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men obliter

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men obliterating and over

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men obli

It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming t

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate.

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate. Stories of ove

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate. If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate. Stories of overcoming something despite the odds or because of the odds, that's what makes for a powerful tale. I

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate. Stories of overcoming something despite the odds or because of the odds, that's what makes for a powerful tale. If we stopped tr

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate. Stories of overcoming something despite the odds or because of the odds, that's what makes for a powerful tale. If we stopped trying, if we stopped taking risks or stopped offering them, then aren't we depriving ourselves of knowing what the meaning of challenge really is?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate. Stories of overcoming something despite the odds or because of the odds, that's what makes for a powerful tale. If we stopped trying, if we stopped taking risks or stopped offering them, then aren't we depriving ourselves of knowing what the meaning of challenge really is?

If our mentality i

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate. Stories of overcoming something despite the odds or because of the odds, that's what makes for a powerful tale. If we stopped trying, if we stopped taking risks or stopped offering them, then aren't we depriving ourselves of knowing what the meaning of challenge really is?

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate. Stories of overcoming something despite the odds or because of the odds, that's what makes for a powerful tale. If we stopped trying, if we stopped taking risks or stopped offering them, then aren't we depriving ourselves of knowing what the meaning of challenge really is?

If our mentality is focused on safety, we wou

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate. Stories of overcoming something despite the odds or because of the odds, that's what makes for a powerful tale. If we stopped trying, if we stopped taking risks or stopped offering them, then aren't we depriving ourselves of knowing what the meaning of challenge really is?

If our mentality is focused on safety, we would not have go

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate. Stories of overcoming something despite the odds or because of the odds, that's what makes for a powerful tale. If we stopped trying, if we stopped taking risks or stopped offering them, then aren't we depriving ourselves of knowing what the meaning of challenge really is?

If our mentality is focused on safety, we would not have gotten to the m

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports. What are we going to watch instead? E-sports? Where "athletes" are just sitting on their computer and mouse and keyboard and doing absolutely nothing except for playing a video game? We hear those commentators say things like, "the character killed about 15 people in one match," and we call that a sport? Just give me a break.

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate. Stories of overcoming something despite the odds or because of the odds, that's what makes for a powerful tale. If we stopped trying, if we stopped taking risks or stopped offering them, then aren't we depriving ourselves of knowing what the meaning of challenge really is?

If our mentality is focused on safety, we would not have gotten to the moon, we wo

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

I know I sound a little bit angry, but wouldn't you be? I've read our history books when there were no safety involved and people just went all in, doing whatever they felt like doing. We did not get stories about plain old men dying of chest injuries incurred during sports because the protective chest plates was too heavy to come with them everywhere, or protectors were not available, no. We heard stories of mighty men overcoming their fears and coming out on top. Stories like those helped shape our culture, and those stories are sometimes what we want to emulate. Stories of overcoming something despite the odds or because of the odds, that's what makes for a powerful tale. If we stopped trying, if we stopped taking risks or stopped offering them, then aren't we depriving ourselves of knowing what the meaning of challenge really is?

If our mentality is focused on safety, we would not have gotten to the moon, we would not have

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is absolutely a must that we consider extreme sports like mountain climbing to be real sports. We have gone too far in our obsession with safety and in this case I think we have stopped athletes from achieving their full potential. Anyone going in with any dangerous sports already have learned about the risks and dangers associated with it, so why be overly cautious?

It's on you, the athlete who fail to prepare or neglect to respect risks, not the organizers who incorporate safety measures. It's also not on spectators that have paid, and paid a great deal of money to go support and watch the athletes do what they love. It's on you, the athlete who failed to get any sort of life insurance to keep their loved ones protected just in case of the unlikely event of an accident happening.

If we don't consider sports like mountain climbing, parachuting, skydiving, running with the bulls, etc to be a real sport then it's going to be a sad day when we hit a patch of very mundane and very uninteresting sports.
